docs.lead_paragraph: The people who answer questions and process claims at the state's biggest health insurer, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey, went on strike at midnight, said Patrick J. Tully, a union spokesman. Negotiations between the company and the union representing 1,700 customer service representatives, claims processors and claims adjusters broke down yesterday afternoon, a state mediator said. Sticking points include the number of paid sick days, which management wants to reduce, and whether pay increases would be retroactive to May 5, when the contract expired, said Mr. Tully, business manager for the Office and Professional Employees International Union Local 32.
docs.abstract: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey customer service representatives go on strike (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Having agreed on the general outlines of a plan to balance the budget, Congress will soon begin a major effort to redesign Medicare, and the process has already set off a fierce legislative struggle that pits elderly people, hospitals, doctors and other health care providers against one another. Congress has agreed to cut projected Medicare spending by $115 billion, or 8.5 percent, in the next five years but has not made any final decisions about how.

headline.main: BATTLE LINES FORM IN MEDICARE FIGHT

docs.abstract: Decision by Congress to cut Medicare spending by $115 billion, or 8.5 percent, over next five years to comply with new budget-balancing agreement sets off fierce legislative struggle that pits elderly, hospitals, doctors and other health care providers against each other; each group wishes to protect its share of $1.2 trillion to be spent by Medicare during period and is using lobbying strategy of appealing to equity and fairness and arguing that others should bear larger share of cuts; Republicans and Democrats in Congress say objective of cuts is not only to save money, but also to modernize Medicare by giving beneficiaries wider choice of competing health plans, including health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 2-7 Conservatives in France Are Rebuffed in Elections President Jacques Chirac of France, a conservative, was rebuffed in his gamble to use legislative elections to gain a mandate for the deficit cutting that he said was needed to join a common European currency in 1999. Instead, the French voted heavily for the leftist opposition and protest parties, raising the chances that the Socialists could lead a majority in Parliament after runoff elections next Sunday. 1 A Stunning Result in Iran Near-final results announced after Iran's presidential election showed the dimensions of the upset victory by a moderate cleric, Mohammed Khatami, who won a surprising 69 percent of the vote. Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, his principal opponent, took just 25 percent. Never in 18 years of Islamic rule had Iranians so clearly rejected the will of the ruling Shiite Muslim clerics. 1

docs.lead_paragraph: As a political scientist, Diana Owen hardly considers herself an expert in women's health. But in spending seven months last year examining the Byzantine ways of Congress, she observed something intriguing. The nation's mostly male legislators, Dr. Owen noticed, seem increasingly inclined to intervene in the way doctors and private health insurance companies conduct themselves when the patients are women.

headline.main: Many Women Wary of Congress's Newfound Interest in Female Health Issues

docs.abstract: Women's health has become potent issue in Congress, but some advocates for women are suspicious of underlying paternalism that feeds spectrum of bills ranging from insurance coverage for mammograms to length of covered maternity stays to restrictions on late-term abortions; note that laws seldom focus on the reproductive functions of men (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HERE come the headaches, right ahead of the bride. Will the limousine be on time? Is Aunt Margaret seated at the right table? Is there music to fill in when the band takes a break? More importantly, can you afford it all? For the lucky ones, all that is turned over to a wedding planner. ''I tell my clients, 'Don't you get stressed out,' '' says Robbi Ernst, one such consultant. ''That's what you're paying me to do -- live with your stress.''

headline.main: One Career Path: Grooming the Bride

docs.abstract: Robbi Ernst, president of June Wedding Inc, is offering wedding-planning course at Norwalk Community-Technical College; Ernst notes that weddings are big part of $32 billion annual event planning business, and he sees wedding planning as good career choice; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE ancient biblical plagues, creepy crawly creatures often cause suburban homeowners to feel besieged, especially during warm weather. Whether there are ants in the kitchen, mice in the attic, beetles on the rosebushes or lice in the children's hair, the usual impulse is to attack the pests with all the chemical artillery the hardware store can muster. But amid growing concern about health hazards at home and in the schools, particularly from routine spraying, the parent-teacher associations of Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry, Hastings-on-Hudson and Irvington earlier this month sponsored a community education program about alternatives to pesticides.
docs.abstract: Parent-teacher associations of Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry, Hastings-on-Hudson and Irvington, NY, concerned about health hazards at home and in schools, sponsor community education program on alternatives to pesticides; hold presentation on integrated pest management, technique that monitors prevalence of pests and eliminates them by getting rid of their food and water sources and shelters (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS Robert Z. Morris was building a fortune in southern Indiana grain and Florida real estate, his mind often flashed back to a scene from his youth. It was the middle of the Depression and his father was desperately trying to borrow money to keep his farm and grain elevator going. Finally, he turned to his life insurance policy. Mutual of Omaha came through with $500, and the family business was saved. That powerful lesson left the younger Mr. Morris with a deep faith in the value of life insurance. As the years rolled by and his own business empire flourished, he became as addicted to insurance as some investors are to the stock market. In 1934, he started with a $5,000 policy that named his wife as beneficiary. From then on, he snapped up policies ''off and on for all of my life,'' he said, believing he was buying protection for his family and an investment vehicle for passing on his wealth. He ultimately acquired nearly 100 policies that he expected would pay roughly $30 million on his death, squirreling them away in an office vault. To keep track, he had a secretary draw up a list of the policies in longhand on a pale green ledger sheet.
docs.abstract: Robert Z Morris, wealthy man who over years acquired life insurance policies that would have paid some $30 million on his death, is suing to recover part of fortune he lost switching some of policies 12 years ago into policies offering higher returns; insurers Manufacturers Life Insurance Co and American General Life Insurance Co and insurance agent James W O'Neill battle claim, holding Morris is sophisticated investor and deal was explained fairly; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 73-year-old Yonkers man had never been much of a drinker. He spent his career in the newspaper business and his free time collecting trophies and medals from racing his Harley-Davidson motorcycle. But in the last five years, the things he cared about most began to pass from his life. At 68, he retired from his job. He could no longer ride his motorcycle. His health deteriorated; he had a heart attack, followed by crippling arthritis.

headline.main: Answering the Needs Of Elderly Alcoholics

docs.lead_paragraph: In the fiscal year that ended April 30, the Intrepid, a decommissioned aircraft carrier that opened as a museum in 1982, turned a small profit, $70,000. The year before it lost $1.2 million, another setback in a checkered financial history that includes bankruptcy. The fiscal turnaround came eight months after the arrival of Donald Ray Gardner, a retired Marine Corps major general, as the museum's president and chief executive officer. Mr. Gardner cut the staff to 120 from 135, trimmed expenses like phone bills and insurance, and transferred costly-to-maintain ''assets'' -- like the Nantucket, a Coast Guard lightship -- to the H.M.S. Rose Foundation in Bridgeport, Conn.

headline.main: Skipper Cuts Costs and Thins Out Intrepid Museum

docs.lead_paragraph: As he left the White House on Tuesday, Trent Lott threw some gorilla dust at Bill Clinton. (Ross Perot's term for one alpha male trying to out-swagger another.) Of course, we expect less from our alpha males here. This is, after all, a city where Larry King, John McLaughlin and Alan Greenspan are the major stud muffins. So what if Mr. Lott puts on a peppermint-striped vest and sings the poppa-oom-poppa-mow-mow chorus of ''Elvira'' in a barbershop quartet called the ''Singing Senators''? Or if he attended a motorcycle rally at the San Diego Convention wearing a fake ponytail attached to his helmet?
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed article on surprise speech by Sen Trent Lott blasting Air Force over Lt Kelly Flinn's prosecution; says Lott summed up what many Americans thought when he said Pentagon was 'not in touch with reality,' and he dealt blow to Pres Clinton, who does not need to have Lott remind everyone that he is steering clear of matter (M)
